tossups.question: This artist’s etchings depicting himself “open-mouthed” and “wide-eyed” functioned as studies for expressions in his renditions of Christ on the Cross and The Raising of Lazarus. This artist’s portrait of a “noble Slav” recalls his many portraits depicting himself in oriental costume. Self-portraits by this artist include one of him as the Apostle Paul and one in front of a pair of (*) circles. He also painted his son Titus wearing a monk’s habit. This artist used himself as the model for a depiction of the Prodigal Son in a tavern that, like many of his self-portraits, depicts his wife Saskia. For 10 points, name this Dutch artist of over 90 self-portraits, who also painted group portraits like The Syndics of the Drapers Guild and The Night Watch.
tossups.answer: Rembrandt van Rijn [or Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn] <RK, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: Panna Bhatt is angered by a production of this play at the opening of Bharati Mukherjee’s “A Wife’s Story.” This is the final and best-known play performed hilariously fast in a one-act parody by David Ives. This play’s third scene includes a rambling monologue in which a man sums up his sexual encounters with the line “She gives me a cigarette, my balls feel like concrete. Eh?” That monologue from this play is delivered to the timid James Lingk at a (*) Chinese restaurant, where the claim that people named Patel are “lonely” and “like to feel superior” is made by Dave Moss. An office is ransacked between this play’s two acts when, hoping to win a Cadillac, Shelley Levene steals the title leads. For 10 points, name this play centering on a competition between a group of salesman, written by David Mamet.
tossups.answer: Glengarry Glen Ross (The second line refers to Speed-the-Play.) <AR, Drama>
tossups.metadata: The second line refers to Speed-the-Play.

tossups.question: It’s not science, but this discipline’s central topic of study is likened to a boat repaired by sailors on the open sea in a metaphor proposed by Otto Neurath (“NOY-rot”). Defenses for “perpetual” and Christian forms of practice are provided by an approach to this field advocated by the philosophers William Alston and Alvin Plantinga, called its “reformed” variety. An approach to this branch of philosophy called foundationalism is one solution to the (*) regress argument. A common definition used in this field originates in the dialogue Theaetetus (“thee-uh-TEE-tuss”). Jones and Smith are discussed in one of the problems in this field named for Edmund Gettier (“GETTY-er”), which challenge the Platonic definition of its central concept as “justified true belief.” For 10 points, name this field of philosophy that studies knowledge.
tossups.answer: epistemology [accept reformed epistemology or Christian epistemology; prompt on philosophy; prompt on knowledge, philosophy of knowledge, or study of knowledge until “knowledge” is read] <WA, Phil/Thought>
tossups.answer_formatted: epistemology [accept reformed epistemology or Christian epistemology; prompt on philosophy; prompt on knowledge, philosophy of knowledge, or study of knowledge until “knowledge” is read]
promptable: study of knowledge until “knowledge” is read

tossups.question: The chronicler Walter Bower exalted the “charming and witty eloquence” of this kingdom’s queen Ermengarde de Beaumont. Another queen of this kingdom was canonized as St. Margaret. A dynastic crisis in this kingdom resulted when Margaret, Maid of Norway, died at age 7. A queen of this kingdom lost public support after the murder of her secretary, David Rizzio, by her husband (*) Lord Darnley. This kingdom’s Covenanter sect led opposition to the introduction of the Book of Common Prayer, since some elements of it ran counter to the teachings of John Knox. This kingdom and its southern neighbor were jointly ruled by Queen Anne after the Act of Union. For 10 points, name this Celtic kingdom whose 16th-century queen Mary was imprisoned.
tossups.answer: Scotland [or Alba] (Bower wrote the Scotichronicon.) <NC, European History>

tossups.question: It’s not integration, but the operator norm of the function defined by this task is called the Lebesgue (“luh-BEG”) constant. A multivariate form of this procedure is used to form a digital elevation model from a contour map. In one method of performing this task, each term in a sequence is multiplied by a normalized sinc function. In one method for this task, Chebyshev nodes minimize an effect in which (*) endpoints oscillate as the degree increases; that effect is named for Runge (“ROON-guh”). The nearest-neighbor method for this task uses piecewise constant functions, while another method for this task simply links points with linear functions. For 10 points, name this task of inferring new data points within the boundaries of an already known set of data points.
tossups.answer: interpolation [or word forms; accept specific examples like polynomial interpolation; prompt on imputation or word forms like impute] <EM, Applied Math/Misc>
tossups.answer_formatted: interpolation [ or word forms; accept specific examples like polynomial interpolation; prompt on imputation or word forms like impute]

tossups.question: In a tale from this book, the movements of an unlucky man chart out the figure of a stork, only for the man to see a stork the next day. This book’s second section examines a legal dispute among a group of “squatters” after two children are accidentally shot, while fragmented anecdotes comprise its fourth section, “Notes From an Immigrant’s Handbook.” The narrator of this book witnesses large dances called ngomas and has an affair with a (*) big-game hunter who dies in a plane crash named Denys Finch-Hatton. Written by a divorced baroness, this book opens “at the foot of the Ngong Hills” and was completed after its author’s coffee plantation went bankrupt and she moved back to her native Denmark. For 10 points, what memoir recalls Karen Blixen’s time in Kenya?
tossups.answer: Out of Africa <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: A choral piece by this composer begins with eight voices entering in turn on the same F before they diverge into chromatic and diatonic clusters. This composer ranged dynamics from four p’s to six f’s in an étude that evokes the title construct by repeatedly ascending the entire piano in chromatic eighth notes. In his only opera, Piet (“peet”) the Pot enters and speaks with the Prince of Hell, Nekrotzar, after 12 car horns blow. He composed the “Devil’s Staircase” étude, the opera (*) Le grande macabre (“luh grond muh-COB”), and Poème symphonique for 100 metronomes. Several of this composer’s avant-garde pieces based on the Requiem mass were used without permission by Stanley Kubrick in 2001: A Space Odyssey. For 10 points, name this Hungarian composer who used “micropolyphony” in Lux Aeterna and Atmosphères (“aht-mohs-FAIR”).
tossups.answer: György Ligeti (“LIG-uh-tee”) [or Ligeti György Sándor] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: This figure legendarily gave the squirrel its stripes when he stroked its back. A tradition of folk plays, or lila, about this figure’s life grew out of Tulsidas’s (“tul-see-DOSS’s”) interpretation of his story. This figure kills the demoness Taraka when she attempts to interrupt the prayers of the rishis, including his mentor Vishvamitra (“veesh-vuh-MEE-truh”). The festival of Dussehra, which celebrates this figure’s victory, is followed by the celebration of his triumphant return on (*) Diwali. This figure meets the dying vulture Jatayu (“JUH-tuh-yoo”), who tells him of how his wife was distracted by a golden deer and abducted by a flying chariot. This elder brother of Lakshmana is aided by Hanuman in his struggle against the king of Lanka. Ravana (“RAH-vuh-nuh”) is defeated by, for 10 points, what seventh avatar of Vishnu and namesake of a Sanskrit epic?
tossups.answer: Rama [or Ramachandra; do not accept or prompt on “Brahma”] <AR, Myths/Legends>
tossups.answer_formatted: Rama [or Ramachandra; do not accept or prompt on "“Brahma”"]

tossups.question: This quantity equals the space integral of the electron number density to the five-thirds power in the Thomas–Fermi formalism. In the time-independent Schrödinger equation, this quantity is directly proportional to [read slowly] “the negative of the reduced Planck’s constant squared times the Laplacian.” This non-vector quantity, typically denoted T, forms the positive term in the simple formula for the (*) Lagrangian. This quantity is [emphasize] not conserved in inelastic collisions. A simple spring’s value for this quantity is [emphasize] maximized at the point of zero displacement. For 10 points, name this type of energy often given by the formula one-half mass times velocity-squared, and which is contrasted with potential energy.
tossups.answer: kinetic energy [prompt on energy; prompt on K or T] <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: A sculpture that is uniquely made entirely of this material depicts a lion-headed eagle holding two deer and is called the Imdugud Relief. An artifact made of this material and named for the island of Laguna is the earliest known inscription found in the Philippines. In the ancient Mediterranean, this material was mixed along with a different material that was imported en masse from Britain. This material was used to make the (*) blade of Otzi’s axe during the Eneolithic. The Greek word for this material sometimes names the period that succeeded the Stone Age, Chalcolithic Period. Cyprus contributed to ancient Eastern Mediterranean trade networks primarily as an exporter of this material. For 10 points, name this metal that can be combined with tin to make bronze.
tossups.answer: copper <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.question: The Letter of Tansar was written by a priest of this empire to justify its historical legacy relative to its predecessors. Shemon Bar Sabbae (“shim-OON bar sa-BYE”) refused to pay a double tax and was executed in this empire, whose priesthood maintained three great fires, whereas their predecessors only had one. A non-Spanish Kingdom of Iberia adopted Orthodox Christianity in defiance of this empire, which executed the founder of (*) Manichaeism for challenging the authority of its Magi priests, but relaxed those policies under Yazdegerd I. After the Battle of Edessa, Emperor Valerian was captured and used as a footstool by the first of this empire’s five rulers named Shapur. For 10 points, name this successor of the Parthian Empire, the last non-Islamic empire to rule Persia.
tossups.answer: Sassanid Empire [or Sasanian Empire or Eranshahr; prompt on Persia or Persian Empire] <ML, World History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Sassanid Empire [or Sasanian Empire or Eranshahr; prompt on Persia or Persian Empire]

tossups.question: Etheridge Knight’s poem “The Sun Came” responds to a poem by this author that ponders the question “And if sun comes / How shall we greet him?” This author included “truth” in “The Womanhood” section of a collection whose second section adapts Chaucer’s rhyme royal for a 43-stanza mock-epic titled “The Anniad (“ANN-ee-add”).” A poem by this author describes the “tobacco crumbs, vases and fringes” of “a rented back room” where “Dinner is a (*) casual affair” for an “old yellow pair” who “are Mostly Good.” This author repeated a pronoun at the end of each line of a poem that uses single-syllable words to depict “Seven at the Golden Shovel” who “left school,” “lurk late,” and “strike straight.” For 10 points, name this African-American poet of “The Bean Eaters” and “We Real Cool.”
tossups.answer: Gwendolyn Brooks <JZ, Poetry>

tossups.question: Statherin prevents calcium phosphate precipitation in this substance. The glands that produce this substance can be affected by pleomorphic adenomas or Warthin’s tumor. Histidine-rich histatins are found in this substance. They’re not tears, but people with Sjögren’s (“SHO-gren’s”) syndrome do not produce enough of this substance. The stimulated form of this substance is produced in the (*) parotid (“puh-ROT-id”) glands. Aerodamus swiftlets use this substance to construct their nests, which are used to make bird’s nest soup. When human babies produce this substance, it contains extra lipase to help digest whole milk. For 10 points, name this fluid, two to three pints of which are generated every day to make the mouth water.
tossups.answer: saliva [prompt on mouth water or spit] <JZ, Biology: Medicine>

tossups.question: A devout Nichiren Buddhist who mainly played this instrument was known for signature “licks” and won two Grammys for his final album Pilgrimage, released the year he died of leukemia. Michael Brecker played this instrument, which dominates the melody of the song “Harlem Nocturne,” which makes extensive use of “growling.” Another player of this instrument scored a Grammy-winning hit on his album Breathless with (*) “Forever in Love.” Players of this instrument include the player of “Mercy, Mercy, Mercy,” Cannonball Adderley, as well as Sonny Rollins and the smooth jazz artist Kenny G. This instrument comes in soprano, baritone, and alto varieties. For 10 points, name this instrument played by a jazz musician nicknamed “Bird,” Charlie Parker.
tossups.answer: saxophone [accept specific types like tenor saxophone or alto saxophone] <WA, Other Arts: Music>
tossups.answer_formatted: saxophone [accept specific types like tenor saxophone or alto saxophone]

tossups.question: A 2015 survey by this country’s Integrity Watch found that its citizens paid about 3 billion dollars in bribes that year, more than the entire budget of its National Unity Government. This country’s current government has neglected to enforce its laws against the brutal rape of young boys by elders engaging in “boy play” or bacha bazi. The US arrested Haji Bagcho, a drug trafficker who helped turn this country into the main (*) production center within the Golden Crescent. A Shi’a minority group primarily found in this country, the Hazara, speak a dialect of Dari with Mongolian and Turkic influence. This country produces most of the world’s opium, which funds a militant group that has made many attempts to take its city of Kandahar. For 10 points, name this country where an Islamic emirate may soon be re-established by the Taliban.
tossups.answer: Afghanistan [or Islamic Republic of Afghanistan] <WA, Geography>

tossups.question: This theory predicts both a spectral index of one and a random distribution of temperature fluctuations at the surface of last scattering. This theory is quantized by a scalar field whose coupling constant, denoted with the Greek letter xi (“k’sigh”), characterizes coupling with gravitons. This theory is the most widely accepted explanation for why some causal (“CAUSE-al”) patches cannot be observed, which is termed the horizon problem, but it does not completely account for (*) anisotropies (“an-eye-SAW-truh-peez”) observed by the COBE (“KO-bee”) satellite. Alan Guth (“gooth”) proposed this theory, whose namesake process took place 10-to-the-negative-36 seconds [emphasize] after a singularity 13 billion years ago. For 10 points, name this theory, according to which the universe expanded very rapidly for a short period after the Big Bang.
tossups.answer: cosmic inflation [do not accept or prompt on “Big Bang”] <WA, Astronomy>
tossups.answer_formatted: cosmic inflation [do not accept or prompt on "“Big Bang”"]

tossups.question: Embracing a “mindset of change” can help these people work “with poverty in mind” according to Eric Jensen, who suggests they use such techniques as “restorative circles.” These people are redistributed in order to assuage criticism of their performance in the so-called “dance of the lemons.” Individuals served by these people are viewed as containers, into whom these people make “deposits,” in a “banking model” criticized by (*) Paulo Freire (“FRAY-ree”). An Italian woman theorized that these workers can achieve “spontaneous discipline” by serving as “directors” who allow discovery and play. The fact that examples of these workers in poor neighborhoods are less talented contributes to the “achievement gap.” Maria Montessori belonged to, for 10 points, what profession analyzed in the documentary Waiting for Superman?
tossups.answer: teachers [or educators or professors; prompt on academics; do not accept or prompt on “social workers” or “counselors”] <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>
tossups.answer_formatted: teachers [or educators or professors; prompt on academics; do not accept or prompt on "“social workers”" or "“counselors”"]

tossups.question: When creditors pursue outstanding debts prior to this holiday, debtors often hide in temples to city gods to wait them out. In an origin story about this holiday, an old beggar convinced villagers to hang pictures on their door and beat drums. Before this holiday, pictures of a household deity are rubbed with honey before being burned; that picture of the (*) Kitchen God is then replaced. Sweeping towards a room’s interior symbolizes good luck during this holiday, on which children often wake up with red paper packets filled with money under their pillows. The Lantern Festival occurs 15 days after, for 10 points, what Asian celebration that features lion dances and heralds a transition to a new zodiac symbol?
tossups.answer: Chinese New Year [or Spring Festival or Chun Jie or Yuan Dan; prompt on New Year; prompt on Lunar New Year by asking “from which specific country?”] <AA, Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: Chinese New Year [or Spring Festival or Chun Jie or Yuan Dan; prompt on New Year; prompt on Lunar New Year by asking “from which specific country?”]
promptable: Lunar New Year by asking “from which specific country?”

tossups.question: An Australian missionary claims that the protagonists of this novel have “Satan in their eyes” after they read in reverse to her. This novel references Heart of Darkness in its discussion of an Englishman who has “gone native” in the abandoned “History House.” In this novel, a biracial child drowns during a boating accident shortly before policeman savagely beat a Communist who works for (*) Paradise Pickles & Preserves. This novel reflects the harm of the “Love Laws” when the title character is killed for crossing caste lines through his relationship with Ammu. At the end of this novel set in the village of Aymanam, the fraternal twins Estha and Rahel reunite in 1993 and commit incest. For 10 points, identify this Booker-winning debut novel by Arundhati Roy.
tossups.answer: The God of Small Things <AR, Long Fiction>
tossups.answer_formatted: The God of Small Things <AR, Long Fiction>
acceptable: The God of Small Things <AR, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: G. Harrold Carswell’s Supreme Court nomination was sabotaged when a Nebraska senator of this ethnicity claimed that “mediocre judges… and people” like him were entitled to representation on the court. Members of this ethnicity frequently settled in industrial suburbs like Hamtramck (“ham-TRAM-ick”), Michigan, and Parma, Ohio. A probably-intersex Revolutionary War hero of this ethnicity died leading a cavalry charge at the Battle of (*) Savannah and names a holiday celebrated mostly in Chicago. Many people of this ethnicity flocked to the United States after the January Uprising. With Irish and Italian-Americans, people of this ethnicity constituted the majority of so-called “white ethnics” who largely switched from the Democratic to the Republican Party in the 1970s. For 10 points, give this ethnicity of Tadeusz Kościuszko (“ta-DAY-oosh kosh-CHOOSH-ko”) and Casimir Pulaski.
tossups.answer: Polish-Americans [accept Poles or Polacks] <JM, US History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: In a story set in this group of islands, the missionary MacPhail kills himself after being seduced by the prostitute Sadie Thompson during a lengthy quarantine. For 10 points each:
answers: Samoan Islands [or Motu o Sāmoa; accept Western Samoa or American Samoa; prompt on Polynesia]
spy [or secret agent; or secret intelligence; accept Ashenden: Or the British Agent; do not accept or prompt on “detective”] (That author is Ian Fleming.)
George Orwell [or Eric Arthur Blair] <JM, Short Fiction>
parts: Name this setting of W. Somerset Maugham’s (“mawm’s”) story “Rain.” Robert Louis Stevenson lived his final years in this group of islands, home to his tombstone engraved with his poem “Requiem.”

Maugham also wrote stories about a man of this profession named Ashenden. Maugham inspired many of the stories and novels about a man of this profession written at a British author’s estate in Jamaica.

Maugham evoked colonial Malaysia in stories like “Footprints in the Jungle,” likely inspiring this British author to describe his time as a police officer in Burma in his essay “Shooting an Elephant.”
answers_formatted: Samoan Islands [or Motu o Sāmoa; accept Western Samoa or American Samoa; prompt on Polynesia]
spy [or secret agent; or secret intelligence; accept Ashenden: Or the British Agent; do not accept or prompt on "“detective”"]

bonuses.leadin: Population studies on this island tracked wolves for over five decades, noting how their fur coloring lightened from black to gray over time. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island in Lake Superior, the site of the longest predator–prey study of wolves and moose.
Because of this practice, which proliferates recessive traits, the Isle Royale wolf population has been reduced to two. In this practice, closely-related members of a species mate with each other.
Selection pressure for these individuals can offset the effects of inbreeding depression. An example of the advantage conferred by this status is the resistance of CFTR carriers to cholera.

bonuses.leadin: This tsar supposedly often told his son Alexander “Sometimes I think there are only two people in the empire who don’t steal. You and me!” For 10 points each:
answers: Nicholas I [or Nikolay I or Nicholas Pavlovich Romanov; prompt on Nicholas or Nikolay]
parts: Name this tsar who was understandably paranoid throughout his reign as it began with the Decembrist Revolt, in which secret societies called for him to be replaced by his brother Constantine.
This war in the 1850s proved Nicholas I right, as Russian bureaucrats frequently stole money intended for ammunition, contributing to a loss at the Siege of Sevastopol.

In this foggy November 1854 battle, corruption issues were exacerbated by the fact that the Russian general, Prince Menshikov, was actually an admiral who had little experience on land. Lord Raglan’s victory at this battle came to little, however, as Raglan died of dysentery (“DISS-in-TAIR-ee”) months later.
answers_formatted: Nicholas I [or Nikolay I or Nicholas Pavlovich Romanov; prompt on Nicholas or Nikolay]

bonuses.leadin: Much of William H. Riker’s work applies concepts from this field of social science to politics. For 10 points each:
answers: political coalitions [or dominant coalitions; accept The Theory of Political Coalitions; prompt on alliance or blocs; do not accept or prompt on “lobbies” or “cliques”]
voting [or electing officials or election; accept The Calculus of Voting] <WA, Social Science: Political>
parts: Name this field of applied mathematical social science whose common tools include backwards induction and payoff matrices.

Riker’s books applying game theory include one on the “theory of” these entities that uses game theory to postulate a “size principle” to limit the number of their members. Cyert and March postulated that elites form “dominant” examples of these entities to control firms and governments.

Another of Riker’s books uses game theory to study the “calculus” of this action and adapts a model proposed by Anthony Downs. Systems for deciding this action’s outcomes include “first-past-the-post.”
answers_formatted: political coalitions [or dominant coalitions; accept The Theory of Political Coalitions; prompt on alliance or blocs; do not accept or prompt on "“lobbies”" or "“cliques”"]
voting [or electing officials or election; accept The Calculus of Voting]

bonuses.leadin: For a tetrahedral complex containing a metal and four equivalents of a ligand (“LIG-und”), this quantity is four-ninths of what it would be for an analogous octahedral complex of the same metal and six of those same ligands. For 10 points each:
answers: crystal-field splitting parameter [or CFSE; accept ligand-field splitting parameter or LFSE; accept crystal-field stabilization energy; prompt on crystal-field splitting energy]
parts: Name this parameter, symbolized delta, that quantifies the difference in energy of the d orbitals of a metal in a coordination complex. This parameter is used to order the spectrochemical series.
For a given principal quantum number, there are this many d orbitals. Atoms surrounded by this many ligands can take on trigonal bipyramidal geometry.
This ligand is found second on the spectrochemical series, after CH2. This molecule complexes with nickel in the Mond process and has a 200-fold greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen.
answers_formatted: crystal-field splitting parameter [or CFSE; accept ligand-field splitting parameter or LFSE; accept crystal-field stabilization energy; prompt on crystal-field splitting energy]

bonuses.leadin: This artist’s painting of the Rucellai (“ROO-chell-eye”) Madonna being carried through the streets by priests was bought almost immediately by Queen Victoria. For 10 points each:
answers: The Lady of Shallot [or Elaine of Astolat; prompt on Elaine] (The poem is by Alfred, Lord Tennyson.) <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Name this British artist of the painting Cimabue’s (“chee-MAH-boo-ay’s”) Celebrated Madonna. This artist’s painting of a long-haired sleeping woman in translucent orange dress is titled Flaming June.
Leighton was associated with the second generation of this art group whose other members included William Holman Hunt and John Everett Millais (“mill-AY”).

This anguished red-headed woman sits in a boat with some candles and a tapestry in a John William Waterhouse painting of her. The title of another Waterhouse painting quotes a poem about this cursed woman from Arthurian legend, in which she claims to be “half-sick of shadows.”
answers_formatted: The Lady of Shallot [or Elaine of Astolat; prompt on Elaine]
metadata: The poem is by Alfred, Lord Tennyson.

bonuses.leadin: Poetry in this language often features alternating “masculine” and “feminine” rhyme styles that are particularly difficult to translate. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this language whose scholars coined the term bylina (“bill-EE-nuh”) to refer to its oldest poems. In a narrative poem in this language, a statue comes to life and rides through the streets after a flood.

This two-word term denotes a period of Symbolist-influenced Russian poetry in the late 19th and early 20th century. Exemplars of this period like Alexander Blok and Anna Akhmatova often met at the Stray Dog Cafe.
The Silver Age was preceded by the Golden Age, which is also called the “Age of” this great Russian poet. He used masculine and feminine rhymes in his verse novel Eugene Onegin.

bonuses.leadin: This concept is exemplified by Sen no Rikyū’s decision to shake some leaves into a perfectly clean garden after sweeping it. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept from Japanese aesthetics in which imperfections, such as a chip on the edge of a teacup, are considered to make an object more beautiful.

Valuing wabi-sabi as part of the transience of the world is derived from the general philosophy of this variant of Mahayana Buddhism popular in Japan, which teaches a type of sudden enlightenment called satori.

Another Japanese concept related to transience, mono no aware (“ah-wah-reh”), is often translated into English as having this concept with respect to things in the world. This word can also refer to an appeal to emotion.

bonuses.leadin: The walls of one of these complexes were supposedly filled with water from the nearby Yamuna River so that it would stay cool during the summer. For 10 points each:
answers: Mughal forts [accept fortifications or Agra Fort or Red Fort]
mirrors [accept Hall of Mirrors] <WA, Other Arts: Architecture>
parts: Give this type of complex, one of which contains a Diwan-i-Am, or audience hall, covered in white plaster. Another of these complexes is named for the color of its sandstone walls.
The Agra Fort is in the same city as this iconic Mughal building, a white mausoleum built by Shah Jahan for his wife Mumtaz.

Within the Agra Fort is the Sheesh Mahal, whose walls are inlaid with mosaics consisting of tiny examples of these objects. A hall at Versailles is named for containing many of these objects on seventeen arches.

bonuses.leadin: A plan of nine square blocks with a central green was created for this city, which was home to a plantation to which many of the regicides, or killers of Charles I, supposedly fled. For 10 points each:
answers: Lenni Lenape [prompt on Delaware until it is read] <ML, US History>
parts: Identify this city whose namesake colony was ruled by Theophilus Eaton. Oliver Winchester founded the first of a cluster of gun manufacturers based in this city, whose best-known university is named for the merchant Elihu (“EL-uh-hyoo”).
Elihu is the namesake of this Ivy League school in New Haven.

Because the New Haven colony signed a treaty with this tribe granting them an area of land that had no Western boundary, Connecticut claimed a narrow strip of land that led all the way to the Pacific Ocean. This tribe, often known as the Delaware, also signed a 1682 treaty with William Penn.
answers_formatted: Lenni Lenape [prompt on Delaware until it is read]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Iraqi scholar Ibn Hanbal, for 10 points each.
answers: the Qur’an is uncreated [or the Qur’an is eternal; or it is coeternal with Allah; or it is the eternal word of God; or it does not have an origin; or that it has always existed, etc.] <JM, Religion>
parts: Ibn Hanbal’s namesake school of jurisprudence is one interpretation of how to apply this code of Islamic law, which is implemented in places such as northern Nigeria and Aceh (“AH-chay”) in Indonesia.
Ibn Hanbal and his later acolyte, Ibn Taymiyyah, were major inspirations of this ultra-conservative Islamic movement that is dominant in Saudi Arabia and sponsored by the country’s monarchy.

During a persecution called the mihna, Ibn Hanbal defended this position regarding the origins of the Qur’an against the rationalist Mu’tazili school. Kharijites and most Shi’a do not accept this position, but all Sunni theological schools do. A description is fine.
answers_formatted: the Qur’an is uncreated [or the Qur’an is eternal; or it is coeternal with Allah; or it is the eternal word of God; or it does not have an origin; or that it has always existed, etc.]
acceptable: it is the eternal word of God
it does not have an origin
that it has always existed, etc.

bonuses.leadin: During an interview for the fawning documentary Rebels of the Sierra Maestra, this leader had his tiny band of soldiers walk in circles in front of TV cameras to magnify their numbers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this leader who attacked the Moncada Barracks in 1953 before capturing Havana six years later.
Castro’s guerrilla movement overthrew this American-aligned dictator, who had earlier staged a coup against Carlos Prio Socarras to avoid losing a 1952 election.

Castro came to Cuba with a small band of guerrillas on a yacht of this name, which in turn names a southeastern province of Cuba. This is also the namesake of the Cuban Communist Party’s official newspaper.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s diary, kept over a period of two years, begins by describing a mansion in autumn, during which the air is filled with the “murmuring sound of waters” and “never-ceasing recitation of sutras.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Pillow Book [or Makura no Sōshi] <WA, Misc Lit>
parts: Identify this pseudonymous medieval author who is named in reference to a shade of violet purple.
Murasaki’s magnum opus is this massive tome, often considered to be the world’s first novel, which follows the title prince’s affairs with many women at the Heian (“hay-on”)-era court in Japan.
Murasaki’s diary documents her fierce rivalry with fellow poet Sei Shōnagon, who is best-known for this zuihitsu (“zoo-ee-heet-soo”) book of fragmentary essays and anecdotes about Heian court life.

bonuses.leadin: 4channers have taken a great liking to a deity from this group, Kek, in part because he had the head of a frog and resembles Pepe, and in part because he represented primordial chaos. For 10 points each:
answers: Set [or Seth or Setesh or Sutekh or Setekh or Suty]
water [accept oceans or seas or salt waters or watery abyss; prompt on abyss or primordial abyss] <ML, Myths/Legends>
parts: Name this group of deities worshipped in Hermopolis. It consists of eight members, four male and four female, each of which represent dualities.
The chaos represented by Kek would later come to be represented by this traitorous brother of Osiris, who was the lord of deserts and chaos.

Nu and Naunet, two deities from the Ogdoad, personified this domain, as did the great serpent Tiamat from Babylonian mythology. In modern times, the Vedic god Varuna is generally associated with this domain.
answers_formatted: water [accept oceans or seas or salt waters or watery abyss; prompt on abyss or primordial abyss]

bonuses.leadin: This penultimate movement of a suite was inspired by Viktor Hartmann’s drawing of a clock that resembles a grotesque mythical abode. For 10 points each:
answers: “The Hut on Fowl’s Legs” [or translations such as “The Hut on Hen’s Legs” or “The Hut on Chicken Feet”; or Baba Yaga or Baba Yaga’s Hut; or “Izbushka na kurih nozhkah” or “La cabane sur des pattes de poule” or “Die Hütte auf Hühnerfüßen”; prompt on The Hut of the Witch]
Night on Bald Mountain [or A Night on the Bare Mountain; or Saint John’s Night on the Bald Mountain; or Saint John’s Eve; or Noch’ na lysoy gore]
parts: Name this sinister C minor scherzo movement in 2/4 (“two-four”) time. It opens with a dissonant falling major seventh from F-sharp to G, played in abrupt pounding low octaves, that builds up to a flight scene in a mortar.
This raucous tone poem by the composer of “The Hut on Fowl’s Legs” was assembled posthumously (“POSS-chuh-miss-lee”) from fragments by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov. It depicts the worship of Chernobog.
This Russian composer, a member of the Mighty Handful along with Rimsky-Korsakov, wrote both Night on Bald Mountain and Pictures at an Exhibition.
answers_formatted: “The Hut on Fowl’s Legs” [or translations such as “The Hut on Hen’s Legs” or “The Hut on Chicken Feet”; or Baba Yaga or Baba Yaga’s Hut; or “Izbushka na kurih nozhkah” or “La cabane sur des pattes de poule” or “Die Hütte auf Hühnerfüßen”; prompt on The Hut of the Witch]
Night on Bald Mountain [or A Night on the Bare Mountain; or Saint John’s Night on the Bald Mountain; or Saint John’s Eve; or Noch’ na lysoy gore]
acceptable: translations such as “The Hut on Hen’s Legs”
“La cabane sur des pattes de poule”
A Night on the Bare Mountain
Saint John’s Night on the Bald Mountain

bonuses.leadin: Quoting from “Stairway to Heaven,” this novel’s epigraph says “There’s a feeling I get when I look to the West….” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this debut novel by Bret Easton Ellis. It follows Clay, who comes home to Los Angeles from his first year of college on the East Coast, then goes on a bunch of adventures with his drug dealer.
Ellis grouped Less than Zero with LA novels in this style, which also denotes classic Hollywood crime drama films like The Big Sleep. This term comes from the French word for “black.”

This other dark novel by Ellis was adapted into a film by Mary Harron and is narrated by the serial killer Patrick Bateman, who works as a Wall Street executive by day and murders people in his apartment by night.

bonuses.leadin: The first democratic assembly in North America, Virginia’s House of Burgesses, convened during this calendar year. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this year of the 17th century in which the first enslaved people were brought to the present-day United States. It titles a recent series of articles by The New York Times examining the legacy of slavery.

An examination of the transatlantic slave trade in the first issue of The 1619 Project was done in collaboration with this organization, which operates the African-American History Museum on the National Mall.

In an August 2019 stage performance commemorating the start of The 1619 Project, this Pulitzer-winning African-American poet read a poem about Crispus Attucks. This Vietnam veteran’s poem “Facing It” recounts his first visit to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Kosterlitz–Thouless transition, a phase transition that occurs in two-dimensional lattices, for 10 points each.
parts: In the KT transition, these sorts of elements transition from paired to unpaired states. This term in general refers to a system that revolves around an axis, such as a tornado or a whirlpool.

Systems undergoing the KT transition lose a continuous example of this property, in this case the U(1) (“U-one”) variety. This property’s translational variety implies conservation of momentum by Noether’s (“NURR-tuh’s”) theorem.

For the KT transition, this value is infinite because the correlation function goes from power law to exponential decay. In the Landau theory of phase transitions, the free energy is expanded as a power series of this quantity.

bonuses.leadin: Benjamin Mitchell and Charles Lambert helped design examples of these objects, one of which is found in the Smithsonian. For 10 points each:
answers: sun stones [accept Piedra del Sol; prompt on stones]
parts: Identify these objects. One of these objects was found under the Zocalo (“SOH-kah-loh”) while renovating the Cathedral in Mexico City, after which it was mounted on the cathedral.
The Sun Stone later immortalized in an Octavio Paz poem was designed by this Mesoamerican civilization centered at Tenochtitlan.

Yet another so-called “sunstone” is a mineral attested in this island’s medieval literature as a navigational tool and may be a variety of transparent calcite. In medieval times, this island was governed by the Althing assembly.

bonuses.leadin: The Dirichlet (“DEE-ree-klet”) function outputs one if the input has this property, and zero if the input does not have this property. For 10 points each:
answers: rational [or rational numbers; or rational function]
maximal [or maximal ideal; do not accept or prompt on “maximum”] <NC, Math>
parts: Name this word that describes a number that can be written as a ratio of two integers. Functions described by this word can be written as the quotient of two polynomials.

The rational numbers, like the real and complex numbers, are an example of this type of algebraic object, which has commutativity, an identity element, and inverse elements for both addition and multiplication operations.

Modding out a ring by an ideal gives a field if and only if the ideal has this property. Zorn’s lemma states that a partially ordered set in which every chain has an upper bound has an element with this property.
answers_formatted: maximal [or maximal ideal; do not accept or prompt on "“maximum”"]
